Oregon’s CTE Plan Approved by U.S. Department of Education

On Friday, May 29, Oregon’s CTE (Career-Technical Education) Plan was approved by the U.S. Department of Education, meaning the state will continue receiving approximately $30 million per biennium to support career and technical education.

In 2019 in Oregon, 51,800 high school students and 53,818 community college students used CTE programs to gain skills necessary to succeed in high-wage, in-demand careers and grow Oregon’s economy. CTE is proven effective to prepare our current and future workforce and grow entrepreneurs who can nimbly create new jobs and stimulate economic growth. Oregon’s CTE programs focus on the knowledge and skills needed to address evolving economic needs and can help our communities through the COVID-19 crisis.

In HSD, approval means we will be able to continue offering professional development to our CTE teachers, and that some will be able to upgrade their industry equipment with approval from their advisory committee.

The safety and well-being of our students is our top priority and we are here to help, as are our community partners. We know that the global pandemic has been challenging in a myriad of ways, and has impacted the mental health of many in our community. Washington County Launches Reopening Status Dashboard

On Wednesday, May 13, Washington County posted a COVID-19 reopening prerequisites dashboard on its website: https://bit.ly/3cHuilq. This will be used to communicate progress toward complying with the Governor’s seven prerequisites for reopening. A complete listing of the prerequisites is available here: https://go.aws/2XdbEes.

At this point, the dashboard reports on the elements within five of the prerequisites for which the County must attain compliance. There are two other prerequisites and a few elements within these five prerequisites that must be achieved at the regional level. These relate to hospital preparedness and testing capacity. In this context, the region refers to the health/hospital region. In our area, this region includes the metro area counties, along with Columbia, Clatsop, and Tillamook counties. The Region 1 Health Preparedness Organization is coordinating the documentation of compliance of the region. When that information is available, it will be added to the site.

Class of 2020 Graduation Plan

The Governor’s extension of school closures through June 30, 2020, and ongoing restrictions on the size of gatherings has removed on-time, in-person graduation ceremonies as a possibility.* However, we still want to recognize and honor our graduates in a way that truly celebrates their many accomplishments throughout their K-12 career, and wishes them well on the next phase of their journey. (*Amended graduation guidance was released by the Oregon Department of Education on Tuesday, May 5, clarifying that no in-person gatherings of more than 24 people - even with social distancing - can take place: https://bit.ly/2YDYYzA.)

Over the past several weeks, we have been brainstorming internally, collecting the best ideas from other school districts, accepting suggestions from parents/community members, and - most importantly - consulting with students on what would be the most meaningful for them.

Here is the plan that will be implemented: www.hsd.k12.or.us/HSD2020GradPlan.

May is the month where we celebrate Asians and Pacific Islanders in the United States and bring awareness to mental health.

The month of May was chosen to commemorate the immigration of the first Japanese to the United States on May 7, 1843, and to mark the anniversary of the completion of the transcontinental railroad on May 10, 1869. The majority of the workers who laid the tracks were Chinese immigrants. To learn more, visit asianpacificheritage.gov.

City of Hillsboro Launches “Food 2 You” Delivery Program

In partnership with St. Vincent de Paul and The Salvation Army of Hillsboro, the City of Hillsboro launched its “Food 2 You” food pantry delivery program on Tuesday, April 7. The program accepts requests and delivers food two days each week to community members who are medically fragile or elderly – those for whom getting to a food pantry may be difficult or dangerous to their health. Requests are taken by phone at 503-681-5090 on Tuesdays and Wednesdays only, from noon to 4 p.m. Orders are filled and delivered the following day (Wednesdays and Thursdays). Community members also have the option to leave a voicemail message to request a callback to take their food request. Food is left at the door in order to maintain social distancing, but with perishable food items, the person must be there to receive the food. Due to high demand, dietary needs or special needs cannot be accommodated. For more information, please see the City’s website: https://bit.ly/3ezk1sV

Sora - The Student Reading App

Did you know that the Hillsboro School District offers free ebooks and audiobooks to students and staff? Our digital collection is available 24/7 - all you need to get started is an internet connection and your device of choice. Either download the app or visit http://soraapp.com/welcome, search for “Hillsboro School District,” and then login using your HSD e-mail and password.

Hillsboro Sustainability Plan Survey

The City of Hillsboro is getting ready to update its Community Environmental Sustainability Plan and wants to hear from you.

Please take a few moments to share your ideas for:
Transitioning to a clean energy future
Protecting and enhancing environmental resources
Advancing resource recovery and renewal

Complete the survey at Hillsboro-Oregon.gov/ESPupdate by Tuesday, Mar. 17.

Hillsboro has made great progress in a variety of environmental sustainability areas, including:
A 10% reduction in residential energy use since 2010,
65% of total community electricity use offset with renewable energy credits purchased by families and businesses,
Dozens of riparian and upland acres conserved or being managed, and
Total community water use reduced 32% since 2002.

But there is more work to be done! Help build the next-generation community environmental sustainability plan.

National Engineers Week

February 16 through 22 was National Engineers Week - a week-long celebration of all things engineering with an emphasis on bringing STEM skills to life for students. To commemorate the event, more than 160 Intel volunteers spent Thursday and Friday, Feb. 20 and 21, leading a fun, hands-on engineering activity with more than 1,500 fourth-graders across the District. The activity involved groups of students working with their adult mentor to build catapults that could launch a ping-pong ball into the air, allowing a team member to catch it like a “pop fly.” This is Intel’s third year collaborating with the District and Portland Metro STEM Partnership for National Engineers Week: www.pdxstem.org

Sequoia Gallery + Studios in downtown Hillsboro will host its annual Hip2BSquare non-juried open art show in April. They have once again received a grant allowing them to provide a 12” x 12” wood panel and waive entry fees for each student who would like to enter. Each artist will set the price for their own artwork. Sequoia will retain a 25% commission on all sales. Sold art will stay up for the duration of the show.

Black History Month

February is Black History Month - an opportunity to both remember and honor the struggles, and acknowledge the central role of African Americans in U.S. History. The City of Hillsboro is hosting a special community event (https://bit.ly/2SeHepN) on Tuesday, Feb. 25, to celebrate the 150th anniversary of the ratification into the U.S. Constitution of the 15th Amendment, which granted African American men the right to vote; and throughout the month the Midland Library in Portland is hosting the Youth Curated Black History Traveling Museum (https://bit.ly/36STmlH) - an exhibit created by Black Student Union groups from Portland metro high schools. Check out these and other informative and inspiring events in our area.

School Counseling Appreciation Week

February 3-7 is School Counseling Appreciation Week. Sponsored by the American School Counselors Association (ASCA), the week highlights the unique contributions of school counselors and the tremendous impact they can have in helping students achieve school success and plan for a career. This year’s theme is “School Counselors: Helping Build Better Humans.” We have counselors in each of our 35 schools - please take a moment to thank them for all they do!
